bestBHT.bht: Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, two active women who labored much in the Lord, and Persis, the beloved of the whole church. These women, by their generosity, relieved the poor of the church and provided for the ministers of the Gospel. Their great usefulness and indefatigableness, in serving the interest of their dear Lord with their purses, exemplify the impact that pious females in their sphere can have in extending the truths and blessings of the gospel.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, who labour in the Lord—two active women.

which laboured much in the Lord—referring probably, not to official services, such as would fall to the deaconesses, but to such higher Christian labors—yet within the sphere competent to woman—as Priscilla bestowed on Apollos and others.
Albert Barnes: Pious females, then, as now, were able to do much in their proper sphere to extend the truths and blessings of the gospel.
These names, with the participle rendered 'who labor,' are in the feminine gender, and these were probably two holy women, who performed the function of deaconesses, or who ministered to the sick.
Tryphena and Tryphosa...labored to promote the spread of Christianity.
Marvin Vincent: Tryphaena and Tryphosa. From trufaw to live luxuriously. See on riot, 2 Peter 2:13. Perhaps sisters. Farrar says they are slave - names.
Philip Schaff: The three persons mentioned in this verse were probably deaconesses.
This woman is not only distinguished by the mention of her greater labor, but is called the beloved.
Meyer notices the delicacy of the phrase; not, ‘my beloved,’ as in the case of the men referred to in Romans 16:5; Romans 16:8.
Archibald T. Robertson: Both names come from the same root, the verb τρυφαω, to live luxuriously (James 5:5). Denney suggests 'Dainty and Disdain.'"
Persis (Περσιδα). A freedwoman was so named. She is not Paul's 'beloved,' but the 'beloved' of the whole church.
John Gill: Their labor cannot be understood of their laboring in the word of the Lord, or in the public ministry of it, since this was forbid by the apostle, and therefore would never commend them on account of it.

Their great usefulness and indefatigableness, in serving the interest of their dear Lord with their purses; in relieving the poor of the church, in entertaining and supplying the ministers of the Gospel, as well as by their private instructions, exhortations, and giving an account of their own experience.
She abounded and exceeded in her labor, and is said to be the wife of Rufus.
John Wesley: Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa — Probably they were two sisters.

bhtAttempts.bht: Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, the active and hardworking women, as well as Persis, the beloved of the whole church. These women, who labored much in the Lord, played a significant role in promoting the spread of Christianity. Though their labor may not have been in the public ministry of the word, they served the interests of their dear Lord through their generosity, providing for the needs of the poor and ministering to the ministers of the Gospel. They were dedicated and tireless in their efforts, exemplifying the impact that pious females in their proper sphere can have in extending the truths and blessings of the gospel.

Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, the active women who labored much in the Lord, along with Persis, the beloved of the church. These women, though their labor may not have been in the public ministry of the word, served the interests of the Lord through their generosity and ministering. Their dedication and tireless efforts exemplify the impact pious females in their proper sphere can have in extending the truths and blessings of the gospel.

Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, two active women who labored much in the Lord, and Persis, the beloved of the whole church. These women, by their private instructions and giving an account of their own experience, served the interests of their dear Lord with their purses as they generously relieved the poor, entertained and supplied the ministers of the Gospel. Their dedication and immense usefulness demonstrate the significant role pious females can play in promoting the spread of Christianity.

Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, the two active women who labored much in the Lord, and Persis, the beloved of the whole church. These women, by their generosity, endeavored to relieve the poor of the church and provide for the ministers of the Gospel. Their great usefulness and indefatigableness in serving the interests of their dear Lord, through their purses and private instructions, exemplify the impact that pious females in their proper sphere can have in extending the truths and blessings of the gospel.

Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, two active women who labored much in the Lord, and Persis, the beloved of the whole church. These women, by their generosity, relieved the poor of the church and provided for the ministers of the Gospel. Their great usefulness and indefatigableness, in serving the interest of their dear Lord with their purses, exemplify the impact that pious females in their sphere can have in extending the truths and blessings of the gospel.
